name: Dwarves
description:
The Dwarves suffered a difficult split at the end of God's War, one large group of them found themselves abandoned on a chain of islands, while the biggest group was in the center of the large easter continent, Elathia, and under constant attack by orcs and trolls. Since then those trapped on the islands have become the most adept sailors in the world, finding safety and wealth on the sea. The others have found homes in both mountains and plains, and have formed a caste-based republic.

This has split the dwarves into 4 distinct sub-races, that although they are capable of interbreeding, rarely do.

#### Dwarven Culture in Elthelas

The Dwarves of Elthelas have a deep affinity for underground and contained spaces. Deep in the vaults of the earth, where light is a rare and expensive thing, art rarely takes the form of the visual, though dwarven stonework and sculpture is often of an incredible caliber. Instead music, particularly singing, are greatly valued. Complicated overlapping resonances fill the caverns, and the choirs of Dorun's faithful are unparalleled. The challenges of an underground life also meant dwarves were the first to invent the water-powered and wind up clocks in Elathia.  Productivity and stoicism are highly valued, as is good order. Many terms common among humans are reversed for dwarves. Darkness is considered good and safe, where light is associated with fear, exposure and death. Phrases like 'moving up in the world' are reversed to 'moving down in the world' as how deep in the earth one lives is associated with status. The acquisition of wealth, particularly in the form of precious metals and gems, approaches the status of religion among the dwarves, such that many of the caste restrictions that exist are centered around methods of acquiring wealth such as restrictions on owning wealth generating property, using banking services, etc.

Another unusual aspect among dwarven cultures in Elthelas is their tendency towards republicanism.  Both Curinor and Morrindim are governed by semi-democratic representative bodies. Their is no true landed nobility among the dwarves, and those who manage to become wealthy have as much political clout as those who were born to it.

#### Cultural differences among the Morrind

 The Morrindim share most of the basic cultural traits with other dwarves of Elthelas, except that they have dropped the traditional caste system.  Access to vehicles of wealth generation is more open in Morrind society.  Similarly the Morrind place less emphasis on living deep within the earth. While the terminology and tradition of 'dark/deep' being equated with 'good' remains, the leaders of Morrind society spend their whole lives in the sun aboard ships.
traits: Size: Dwarves stand between 4 and 5 feet tall and average about 150 lbs. Your size is medium.
Dwarven Resilience: You have advantage on saving throws against poison, and you have resistance against poison damage.
Dwarven Combat Training: You have proficiency with the battleaxe, handaxe, throwing hammer, and warhammer.

subraces.name: Deep Dwarves
subraces.description: The Deep Dwarves are the ruling caste of dwarven society in Curinor. They rarely (if ever in their lives) see the sun, preferring to stay in the deepest parts of the dwarven holds. They travel between holds via underground roads or by palanquin, and almost never associate with plains dwarves, let alone non-dwarves. Deep Dwarves have exceedingly pale, almost colorless skin.
traits: Ability Score Increase: Your Constitution score increases by 1 and your wisdom score increases by 2.
Speed: Your base walking speed is 25 feet. Your speed is not reduced by wearing heavy armor.

Darkvision: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 90 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.
Tool Proficiency: You gain proficiency with the artisan's tools of your choice: smith's tools, brewer's supplies, or mason's tools.

Stonecunning: Whenever you make an intelligence (history) check related to the origin of stonework, you are considered proficient in the history skill and add double your proficiency bonus to the check, instead of your normal proficiency bonus.
Noble Blood: You gain proficiency in one skill of your choice choosing from persuasion, performance, intimidation, or deception.

subraces.name: Hill Dwarves
subraces.description: The Hill Dwarves of Curinor are the middle glue of society. Most dwarven craftsmen and warriors are hill dwarves, and they do most of the work in the lucrative mines and smithies of Curinor (although the deep dwarves still see most of the profits). Hill Dwarves are hardy folk, but are ill-accustomed to dealing with non-dwarves. Their skin is fair, but not pale, typically with rose colored undertones.
traits: Ability Score Increase: Your Constitution score increases by 2 and your wisdom score increases by 1.
Speed: Your base walking speed is 25 feet. Your speed is not reduced by wearing heavy armor.

Darkvision: Accustomed to life underground, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.

Dwarven Toughness: Your hit point maximum increases by 1 per character level.

subraces.name: Morrind Dwarves
subraces.description: The Morrind Dwarves were separated from the other dwarves in the God's War, and marooned on a distant island chain. They built a city in which they could remember their mountain home (called Morrind) and learned to build ocean worthy ships. They took to the sea, trading with whomever they could find in order to supply themselves with whatever they needed. By the time they found the other dwarves, they discovered that they were more comfortable at sea then on land, and unwelcome in the caste-system devised by their kin. Morrind dwarves tend to be less hardy but more dextrous compared to their kin, and are very adept at shipboard movement.
traits: Ability Score Increase: Your Constitution score increases by 2 and your Charisma score increases by 1.
Speed: Your base walking speed is 30 feet. Your speed is not reduced by wearing heavy armor.
Tool Proficiency: You gain proficiency with the artisan's tools of your choice: smith's tools, brewer's supplies, or carpenter's tools.

Seacunning: Whenever you make an intelligence (nature) check related to the sea, you are considered proficient in the history skill and add double your proficiency bonus to the check, instead of your normal proficiency bonus.

Natural Sailor: You are considered proficient and may add double your proficiency bonus to any acrobatics check on board a ship, a survival check made to navigate a sea, or an athletics check made to swim, you also gain proficiency with water based vehicles.

subraces.name: Plains Dwarves
subraces.description: Plains Dwarves are the lowest of the low among the dwarves of Curinor. Living primarily on the surface, they are often shunned by other dwarves, however they are more accustomed to interacting with other races, as well as hard manual labor. Nevertheless, they are typically poor and ill-educated. Their life on the open plain has endowed them with a dark tan tone to their skin (particularly compared to the pale deep dwarves).
